results.title: Yugoslavia; Hungary
results.creator_credit: William Fitzwater, Fitzwater Productions and SBS-TV
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Through Australian eyes”.
Depicts the experiences of Australian children of various ethnic backgrounds in the country where their parents were born. “Yugoslavia”: Duska Franic discovers her large extended family when visiting her parents’ birthplace in the beautiful Croatian countryside. “Hungary”: Debbie Karp journeys to Budapest, her mother’s birthplace. She visits relatives and tours Hungary on a voyage of discovery.

results.title: Jessie Thandi in India; Ellen Youie in China = India; China
results.creator_credit: Stephen Cross, William Fitzwater, Argosy Films, Channel 0\28 and Fitzwater Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Through Australian eyes”.
Two programs from the series” Through Australian Eyes”. In the first program Australian-born Jessie Thandi journeys to the Punjab region of India, her father’s place of birth in a search for her own identity. In the second program Ellen Youie visits the small Cantonese village where her mother was born, and strengthens the ties she feels with her Chinese heritage.

results.title: Hockney at the Tate
results.creator_credit: Alan Benson, RM Arts and South Bank Show
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Phaidon art collection”.
Melvyn Bragg interviews David Hockney in this relaxed documentary. Hockney walks through a major retrospective exhibition held at the Tate Gallery London in 1988, starting with his first oil painting, a painting of his father, through his student and early work to his contemporary return to painting. He talks of his move from England to Southern California where he painted his well known pools and splashes. His double portraiture is discussed as is his spatial experiments with composite photography. Hockney talks of his theatre design and his return to painting with his contemporary works featuring curves, bright colours and strange subjective perspectives. The sometimes witty and casual down to earth Hockney ends with a recent portrait of his mother. Edited and presented by Melvyn Bragg.

results.title: Rosencrantz and Guildenstern are dead
results.creator_credit: Tom Stoppard, Emanuel Azenberg, Michael Brandman, Cinecom Entertainment and WNET (Television station : New York, N.Y.)
results.brief_description: Let Richard Dreyfuss, Tim Roth and Gary Oldman take you one a medieval misadventure, getting themselves in and out of trouble to tell the “true” story (with a few hilarious distractions along the way) of one of the most famous stories of all time.

results.title: Rosemary Agostino in Italy; Angela Sarantis in Greece
results.creator_credit: David E. Barrow, Barinder Productions and Channel 0-28
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Through Australian eyes”.
Two programs from the series :Through Australian eyes”. In the first program Rosemary Agostino returns to her parents’ birthplace in Calabria. In the small village she becomes aware of the sense of community missing from life in Australia. In the second program Angela Sarantis returns to her father’s village in Kastraki in northern Greece. She sees that many changes have occurred since her parents left their homeland particularly due to the demands of Greece’s main industry, tourism.

results.title: The Restless eye: Eugene Delacroix: a film based on his paintings and his journals
results.creator_credit: Colin Nears, BBC and RM Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Phaidon art collection”.
Born in France in 1798 and dying in 1863, Eugene Delacroix was one of the most important Romantic painters of his time, earning him the retrospective reputation of, ‘a painter’s painter’ - his work’s being referenced and copied by the likes of Manet, Picasso and Van Gogh. This documentary is based on the journals that Delacroix wrote since age 24 which have since become literary classics in their own right. The writings reveal much of Delacroix’s dilemmas and intentions in his life and art. He was sceptical of progress, disdainful of the masses and scornful of revolution, but also intended to articulate his fascination with the barbarity and violence of ‘humanity’. Declaring, “I’m trying to make a beauty which is not quiet”, Delacroix painted a heady mix of beauty and cruelty with constant movement, colour, and restless energy. Cast includes John Carson as Delacroix.

results.title: Raphael: the prince of painters. [Vol. 2]
results.creator_credit: Ann Turner, BBC and RM Arts
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Phaidon art collection”.
The second of a two volume series, ‘Raphael: the prince of painters’ provides great background to Raphael’s life, influences, education and professional friendships as an artist beyond his apprentice years. The documentary starts with Raphael’s arrival to Rome aged twenty-five. Already famous for his work in Florence this volume focuses on Raphael’s art as a matured vision and reflects on his relationship with the Vatican and Pope Julius the second and his entry into aristocratic high culture at a time of unrivalled confidence and riches in the Catholic Church. Raphael’s tapestry work at the Sistine Chapel and the ‘Transfiguration’ altarpiece are focussed on in this documentary, his philosophy being reflected by his close friendships in humanist thinkers Baldassare Castiglione and Pietro Bembo and architect Donato Bramante. Written and narrated by David Thompson.

results.title: Max Ernst
results.creator_credit: Peter Schamoni, RM Arts and Zweites Deutsches Fernsehen
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Phaidon art collection”.
Traces the history of renowned painter and sculptor, Max Ernst, his personal life as well as artistic career. The program contains extensive interviews and commentary from Ernst himself which details the pattern of his life and work from his founding influence in the Surrealist movement, throughout World War II and his struggles within and without Germany up to his settlement in America and then move back to Europe. Opening with an outline of the commencement of the Dada movement in 1919, the program discusses the life history of Ernst from his move to Paris before World War II and his association and friendship with Paul Eluard along with other founding members of the Surrealist group. The details of his artistic interests in natural history made strange, that is, the confusion of disparate beings and objects in nature through mind and poetic associations, are discussed in terms of his public work as well as that undertaken in more personal spaces such as murals in friends houses and sculptures and exterior murals adorning his own various residences. With the advent of Hitler’s power in Germany, his works as a mirror to a ‘mad time’ are studied, along with the progress of Ernst away from the Surrealist movement before World War II. At the commencement of the war, a trying era began for Ernst of imprisonments at various stages in France for his German citizenship and as a result of false accusations, spending a few months in a concentration camp, which led to his subsequent difficult, but finally successful move to America with the help of colleague and third wife Peggy Guggenheim and the New York art scene. Here the program details his first Surrealist Exhibition in New York and his invention of what is now known as action painting, all received with great critical acclaim, and his following career in New York, during which time he married the painter, Dorothea Tanning. Their move to Arizona, to live and work in a ‘landscape of the minds eye’ signalled a time of detachment from many of his peers and a fascination with Native American culture and crafts and the rythms of the landscape that he had painted before seeing and that manifested a great influence in his works of the time. In the 1950s, his return to Europe was met with little recognition, but following the receipt of the Grand Prix of Venice in 1954, his acclaim saw an establishment of his freedom to experiment with his progression of interests in painting and sculpture once again. The program closes with an analysis of his work at this stage where his final settlement in the ‘Garden of France’ with Dorothea is discussed with reference to the hopeful nuances of his later series of paintings that studied the idea of the cage, and most symbolically, an empty cage from which a bird had escaped.

results.title: Marc Chagall
results.creator_credit: Kim Evans, LWT and RM Arts
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Phaidon art collection”.
At a time when the world was turning toward Modernism. artist Marc Chagall had decided to finally leave his native Russia for Paris, the epi-centre of the art world at the turn of the 20th Century. Having suffered a poor and repressed childhood as a Russian Jew marginalised by poverty and cultural dissent Chagall’s iconography differed from his contemporaries. Whilst employing essentially a cubist surface his subject matter was deeply personal drawing on his life experiences. This documentary explores Chagall’s personal vision as artist and storyteller charting his career through his paintings, set and costume designs and stain glass work. Edited and presented by Melvyn Bragg.

results.title: Christian Boltanski
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Phaidon art collection”.
A comprehensive documentary on one of the most important contemporary artists of 20th Century France, Christian Boltanski. Interviewed by Melvyn Bragg, Boltanski’s childhood influences, mostly the affects of the Holocaust on society in post-war France are explored in direct reference to a series of Boltanski’s work spanning over a period of 30 years. Boltanski’s passion for ethnology, collections and death, as themes central to his art, are discussed in relationship to his work. The subtlety of broad themes are constantly explored in his work: the nature of the killer, heroes and villains, quantifying loss. Boltanski uses mostly photographs in his installation pieces. Works featured in the documentary: ‘Shadows’ (1985); ‘Sans Souci’ (1991); ‘The Reserves’ (1993); ‘The Dead Swiss’; ‘The Art of the Venice Biennale 1938’ (1993); ‘Comical Skits’(1974).

Boltanski’s passion for ethnology, collections and death, as themes central to his art, are discussed in relationship to his work. The subtlety of broad themes are constantly explored in his work: the nature of the killer, heroes and villains, quantifying loss. Boltanski uses mostly photographs in his installation pieces. Works featured in the documentary: ‘Shadows’ (1985); ‘Sans Souci’ (1991); ‘The Reserves’ (1993); ‘The Dead Swiss’; ‘The Art of the Venice Biennale 1938’ (1993); ‘Comical Skits’(1974).
description_for_label:
Episode of Series “Phaidon art collection”.
A comprehensive documentary on one of the most important contemporary artists of 20th Century France, Christian Boltanski. Interviewed by Melvyn Bragg, Boltanski’s childhood influences, mostly the affects of the Holocaust on society in post-war France are explored in direct reference to a series of Boltanski’s work spanning over a period of 30 years. Boltanski’s passion for ethnology, collections and death, as themes central to his art, are discussed in relationship to his work. The subtlety of broad themes are constantly explored in his work: the nature of the killer, heroes and villains, quantifying loss. Boltanski uses mostly photographs in his installation pieces. Works featured in the documentary: ‘Shadows’ (1985); ‘Sans Souci’ (1991); ‘The Reserves’ (1993); ‘The Dead Swiss’; ‘The Art of the Venice Biennale 1938’ (1993); ‘Comical Skits’(1974).
